Text:
red, frothing head, ale, slipped that a special ingredient that only grows at the mountain. 

For 1 hour after drinking this delicious ale crafted by the dwarves of Gunderson Brewing Company, you gain 10 temporary hit points that last for 1 hour. For the same duration, you are under the effect of the bless spell (no concentration required).

A holy symbol is a representation of a god or pantheon.

A cleric or paladin can use a holy symbol as a spellcasting focus. To use the symbol in this way, the caster must hold it in hand, wear it visibly, or bear it on a shield.

A holy symbol is a representation of a god or pantheon.

A cleric or paladin can use a holy symbol as a spellcasting focus. To use the symbol in this way, the caster must hold it in hand, wear it visibly, or bear it on a shield.

A container, usually elaborate, in which its purpose is to hold holy relics

A cleric or paladin can use a holy symbol as a spellcasting focus. To use the symbol in this way, the caster must hold it in hand, wear it visibly, or bear it on a shield.
A druid can use this object as a spellcasting focus.

Add-On-Materials: Dye, Gem, Leather, Metal, Mineral, Textile
Text:
Versatile. This weapon can be used with one or two hands. A damage value in parentheses appears with the property—the damage when the weapon is used with two hands to make a melee attack.
An arcane focus is a special item designed to channel the power of arcane spells. A sorcerer, warlock, or wizard can use such an item as a spellcasting focus.
A druid can use this object as a spellcasting focus.
An arcane focus is a special item designed to channel the power of arcane spells. A sorcerer, warlock, or wizard can use such an item as a spellcasting focus.
A druid can use a Wooden Staff as a spellcasting focus
A druid can use this object as a spellcasting focus.

As an action, you can splash the contents of this flask onto a creature within 5 feet of you or throw it up to 20 feet, shattering it on impact. In either case, make a ranged attack against a target creature, treating the holy water as an improvised weapon. If the target is a fiend or undead, it takes 2d6 radiant damage.

A cleric or paladin may create holy water by performing a special ritual. The ritual takes 1 hour to perform, uses 25 gp worth of powdered silver, and requires the caster to expend a 1st-level spell slot.

Made of interlocking metal rings, chain mail includes a layer of quilted fabric worn underneath the mail to prevent chafing and to cushion the impact of blows. The suit includes gauntlets.

The wearer has disadvantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks.

If the wearer has a Strength score lower than 13, their speed is reduced by 10 feet.

Plate consists of shaped, interlocking metal plates to cover the entire body. A suit of plate includes gauntlets, heavy leather boots, a visored helmet, and thick layers of padding underneath the armor. Buckles and straps distribute the weight over the body.

The wearer has disadvantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks.

If the wearer has a Strength score lower than 15, their speed is reduced by 10 feet.

This armor is leather armor with heavy rings sewn into it. The rings help reinforce the armor against blows from swords and axes. Ring mail is inferior to chain mail, and its usually worn only by those who cant afford better armor.

The wearer has disadvantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks.

This armor is made of narrow vertical strips of metal riveted to a backing of leather that is worn over cloth padding. Flexible chain mail protects the joints.

The wearer has disadvantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks.

If the wearer has a Strength score lower than 15, their speed is reduced by 10 feet.

This armor consists of a fitted metal chest piece worn with supple leather. Although it leaves the legs and arms relatively unprotected, this armor provides good protection for the wearers vital organs while leaving the wearer relatively unencumbered.

Made of interlocking metal rings, a chain shirt is worn between layers of clothing or leather. This armor offers modest protection to the wearers upper body and allows the sound of the rings rubbing against one another to be muffled by outer layers.

Half plate consists of shaped metal plates that cover most of the wearers body. It does not include leg protection beyond simple greaves that are attached with leather straps.

The wearer has disadvantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks.

This armor consists of a coat and leggings (and perhaps a separate skirt) of leather covered with overlapping pieces of metal, much like the scales of a fish. The suit includes gauntlets.

The wearer has disadvantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks.

Spiked armor is a rare type of medium armor made by dwarves. It consists of a leather coat and leggings covered with spikes that are usually made of metal.

The wearer has disadvantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks.
A shield is made from wood or metal and is carried in one hand. Wielding a shield increases your Armor Class by 2. You can benefit from only one shield at a time.
A standard whetstone used to sharpen blades.
1d4 bludgeoning; light
1d8 bludgeoning; Two-handed

Add-On-Materials: Dye, Gem, Leather, Metal, Mineral, Textile
Text: 1d6 bludgeoning; versatile (1d8)

Speed: 8 mph
Carrying Capacity: 1 ton cargo, 20 passengers
Crew 10, AC 13, HP 300

Speed: 10 mph
Carrying Capacity: 10 tons cargo, 30 passengers
Personal Travel Cost: 2 gp per mile per passenger
Shipping Cost: 1 gp per 100 pounds per mile
Crew 6-10
It holds up to six Medium creatures and has a maximum speed of 2 mph. It is otherwise identical to a rowboat.

Speed: 4 mph
Carrying Capacity: 150 tons cargo
Crew 80, AC 15, HP 500, Damage Threshold 20

Keelboats and rowboats are used on lakes and rivers. If going downstream, add the speed of the current (typically 3 miles per hour) to the speed of the vehicle. These vehicles cant be rowed against any significant current, but they can be pulled upstream by draft animals on the shores. 
Speed: 1 mph
Carrying Capacity: 1/2 ton cargo, 6 passengers
Crew 1, AC 15, HP 100, Damage Threshold 10

Speed: 3 mph
Carrying Capacity: 10 tons cargo, 150 passengers
Crew 40, AC 15, HP 300, Damage Threshold 15

Keelboats and rowboats are used on lakes and rivers, If going downstream, add the speed of the current (typically 3 miles per hour) to the speed of the vehicle. These vehicles cant be rowed against any significant current, but they can be pulled upstream by draft animals on the shores. A rowboat weighs 100 pounds, in case adventurers carry it over land.
Speed: 1½ mph
Carrying Capacity: 3 passengers
Crew 1, AC 11, HP 50

Speed: 2 mph
Carrying Capacity: 100 tons cargo, 20 passengers
Crew 20, AC 15, HP 300, Damage Threshold 15

Speed: 2½ mph
Carrying Capacity: 200 tons cargo, 60 passengers
Crew 60, AC 15, HP 500, Damage Threshold 20
food made of flour, water, and yeast or another leavening agent, mixed together and baked.
a food made from the pressed curds of milk.
the flesh of an animal as food
main ingredient of bread and many other foods
whole-grain cereal; high in fiber and vitamins
the seed of a type of grass, used in cooking
a major ingredient in various foods
used mainly as an aromatic condiment and flavouring additive in a wide variety of cuisines, sweet and savoury dishes, breakfast cereals, snackfoods, tea and traditional foods
commonly used as a spice
All parts of the plant are edible, but the fresh leaves and the dried seeds are the parts most traditionally used in cooking
Its seeds – each one contained within a fruit, which is dried – are used in the cuisines of many cultures in both whole and ground form
widely used around the world for its pungent flavor as a seasoning or condiment.
is widely used as a spice and a folk medicine
the seed or ground spice
which is usually dried and used as a spice and seasoning.
underground plant parts eaten by creatures as food
dried for use mainly as a seasoning and colouring agent in food
one of the oldest and most ubiquitous food seasonings, and salting is an important method of food preservation.
items worn to cover the body made from common materials, for general occasions.
items worn to cover the body made from various materials, for disguising oneself.
items worn to cover the body made from fine materials, typically for social gatherings.
items worn to cover the body made of various materials, for general journeys or travels.

This outfit consists of a heavy fur coat or cloak over layers of wool clothing, as well as a fur-lined hat or hood, goggles, and fur-lined leather boots and gloves.

As long as cold weather clothing remains dry, its wearer automatically succeeds on saving throws against the effects of extreme cold.
While wearing this clothing: the wearer gains advantage on any animal handling checks, and automatically succeeds on saving throws against the effects of extreme cold. Also water resistant.
While wearing creature-silk clothing you gain advantage on stealth checks
A creature that drinks this vial of liquid gains advantage on saving throws against poison for 1 hour. It confers no benefit to undead or constructs.

This kit is a leather pouch containing bandages, salves, and splints. The kit has ten uses. As an action, you can expend one use of the kit to stabilize a creature that has 0 hit points, without needing to make a Wisdom (Medicine) check.

Ingested. A creature subjected to this poison must make a DC 10 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, it takes 6 (1d12) poison damage and is poisoned for 24 hours. On a successful save, the creature takes half damage and isn’t poisoned.

Injury. You can use this poison to coat one slashing or piercing weapon or up to three pieces of ammunition. Applying the poison takes an action. A creature hit by the poisoned weapon or ammunition must make a DC 10 Constitution saving throw or take 1d4 poison damage. Once applied, the poison retains potency for 1 minute before drying.

Inhaled. A creature subjected to this poison must succeed on a DC 13 Constitution saving throw or take 10 (3d6) poison damage, and must repeat the saving throw at the start of each of its turns. On each successive failed save, the character takes 3 (1d6) poison damage. After three successful saves, the poison ends.

Contact. This poison must be harvested from a dead or incapacitated carrion crawler. A creature subjected to this poison must succeed on a DC 13 Constitution saving throw or be poisoned for 1 minute. The poisoned creature is paralyzed. The creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

Inhaled. Originally used by the eponymous healer to help subdue and quiet wounded or troubled soldiers who were too much for him to handle, others have since come up with more sinister uses. A creature subjected to this substance must succeed on a DC 12 Constitution saving throw or become poisoned for 6 hours. The poisoned creature cannot use their strength modifier (if above 0) to any roll.

injury. Developed by the Jade Assassins, this violet liquid is anathema to spellcasters, draining their arcane energy. A creature subjected to this poison must succeed on a DC 12 Constitution saving throw or become poisoned for 1 minute. The poisoned creature suffers an effect on the Magebane Table. Roll 1d4 for the effect:
Magebane Table
1-2) Lose 1 highest level available spell slot
3-4) Double casting time for all spells requiring spell slots
Inhaled. A creature subjected to this poison must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or become poisoned for 1 hour. The poisoned creature is blinded.

Injury. This insidious poison runs ice through its victim’s limbs. A creature subjected to this poison must succeed on a DC 18 Constitution saving throw or become poisoned for 1 minute. Marrow lock’s victims have their movement hindered. The victim suffers 1d6 poison damage per 5 feet of movement.

Ingested. A creature that ingests this poison suffers no effect until the stroke of midnight. If the poison has not been neutralized before then, the creature must succeed on a DC 17 Constitution saving throw, taking 31 (9d6) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

Contact. A creature subjected to this poison must succeed on a DC 13 Constitution saving throw or become poisoned for 24 hours. The poisoned creature is unconscious. The creature wakes up if it takes damage.

Ingested. Oldroot is a common and relatively harmless plant. The outlanders would chew the resin from the root bulbs to induce vivid hallucinations in which they seek mystic knowledge. Those who ingest oldroot resin must make a DC 15 Constitution check. Those who fail suffer hallucinations according to the Oldroot Hallucinations table. The involuntary actions described last only for 1 minute, but they continue to suffer disorienting minor hallucinations without mechanical effects for up to an hour.
1d6 Oldroot Hallucinations
1. Even the birds are mocking me! The character spends the next minute raving at and attacking something innocuous like a tree, barrel, wagon, shrub, or bird.
2. Get it off! Get it off! Get it off! The character is convinced they are covered by bugs, leeches, snakes, or the like. They spend the next minute swatting at non-existent creepy-crawlies.
3. You did this to me! The character believes one of their comrades had backstabbed them or is otherwise plotting their demise. The character can only take the defend action and yell in outrage at their “betrayer.”
4. The sky, the hideous sky! The character believes that some malign creatures from the sky are about to carry them off (or, for dwarves, that they are going to fall into the sky). The character spends the next minute dropping their weapons and grabbing something solid.
5. The shadows are alive! The character is overcome with fear of the surrounding shadows, including their own. They spend the next minute running at top speed away from the closest concentration of shadows.
6. Foul demon! The character is suddenly convinced that a random nearby ally (determined by the GM) is a demon or other natural enemy. The character spends the next minute attacking that “enemy”.

Ingested. A creature subjected to this poison must succeed on a DC 16 Constitution saving throw or take 3 (1d6) poison damage and become poisoned. The poisoned creature must repeat the saving throw every 24 hours, taking 3 (1d6) poison damage on a failed save. Until this poison ends, the damage the poison deals can’t be healed by any means. After seven successful saving throws, the effect ends and the creature can heal normally.

Injury. This poison must be harvested from a dead or incapacitated purple worm. A creature subjected to this poison must make a DC 19 Constitution saving throw, taking 42 (12d6) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

Injury. This poison must be harvested from a dead or incapacitated giant poisonous snake. A creature subjected to this poison must succeed on a DC 11 Constitution saving throw, taking 10 (3d6) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

Injury. Extracted from the giant arachnids, this poison can render a creature paralyzed. A creature subjected to this poison must succeed on a DC 11 Constitution saving throw, taking 13 (3d8) poison damage on a failed save, or no damage on a successful one. On a failed save, the creature is poisoned for 1 minute, causing the creature to be paralyzed. The creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

Ingested. A creature subjected to this poison must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or become poisoned for 1 hours. The poisoned creature cannot use their dexterity modifier (if above 0) for dexterity checks or saves.

Injury. A creature subjected to this poison must make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw, taking 24 (7d6) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

This poison must be harvested from a dead or incapacitated wyvern.

This paste made from the Snake Vine is known to help prevent sunburn, but it is also a fire retardant. After spending 1 minute applying a quarter pint of muroosa balm to your skin, you gain resistance against fire damage for 1 hour.

A dose of muroosa balm sufficient for treating sunburn costs 1 gp.

When you use your action to set it, this trap forms a saw-toothed steel ring that snaps shut when a creature steps on a pressure plate in the center. The trap is affixed by a heavy chain to an immobile object, such as a tree or a spike driven into the ground. A creature that steps on the plate must succeed on a DC 13 Dexterity saving throw or take 1d4 piercing damage and stop moving. Thereafter, until the creature breaks free of the trap, its movement is limited by the length of the chain (typically 3 feet long). A creature can use its action to make a DC 13 Strength check, freeing itself or another creature within its reach on a success. Each failed check deals 1 piercing damage to the trapped creature.
an oblong frame with rows of wires or grooves along which beads are slid, used for calculating

As an action, you can splash the contents of this vial onto a creature within 5 feet of you or throw the vial up to 20 feet, shattering it on impact. In either case, make a ranged attack against a creature or object, treating the acid as an improvised weapon. On a hit, the target takes 2d6 acid damage.
The stilts take 1 minute to put on or remove. They increase the height of any humanoid wearing them by 2 to 5 feet. Each stilt weighs 8 pounds and is 1 foot long when fully collapsed.

This sticky, adhesive fluid ignites when exposed to air. As an action, you can throw this flask up to 20 feet, shattering it on impact. Make a ranged attack against a creature or object, treating the alchemists fire as an improvised weapon. On a hit, the target takes 1d4 fire damage at the start of each of its turns. A creature can end this damage by using its action to make a DC 10 Dexterity check to extinguish the flames.

A humanoid wearing this piece of gear can deploy the parachute as a reaction while falling, or as an action otherwise. The parachute requires at least a 10-foot cube of unoccupied space in which to deploy, and it doesnt open fast enough to slow a fall of less than 60 feet. If it has sufficient time and space to deploy properly, the parachute allows its wearer to land without taking falling damage. Once it has been used, the parachute takes 10 minutes to repack.

As an action, you can spill these tiny metal balls from their pouch to cover a level area 10 feet square. A creature moving across the covered area must succeed on a DC 10 Dexterity saving throw or fall prone. A creature moving through the area at half speed doesnt need to make the saving throw.

This metal cube, 6 inches on a side, has a crank on top. Using an action to wind the crank activates the box for 8 hours. While activated, the box barks whenever it detects vibrations within 15 feet of it, as long as the box and the source of the vibrations are in contact with the same ground or substance. A switch on one side of the box sets the device to emit either a small dogs bark or a large dogs bark.
A basket holds 2 cubic feet or 40 pounds of gear.
a sleeping bag or other bedding rolled into a bundle
a device that includes or sounds like a bell, used to give a signal or warning.
a large piece of woolen or similar material used as a bed covering or other covering for warmth.

This volatile alchemical powder comes in a small pouch. When ignited by an open flame or a fuse, the powder explodes. Each creature within 5 feet of the exploding pouch must make a DC 13 Dexterity saving throw, taking 3d6 bludgeoning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

A character can bind multiple pouches of blasting powder together so they explode at the same time. Each additional pouch increases the damage by 1d6 (maximum of 10d6) and the blast radius by 5 feet (maximum of 20 feet).
A set of pulleys with a cable threaded through them and a hook to attach to objects, a block and tackle allows you to hoist up to four times the weight you can normally lift.

A book might contain poetry, historical accounts, information pertaining to a particular field of lore, diagrams and notes on gnomish contraptions, or just about anything else that can be represented using text or pictures. A book of spells is a spellbook.
A bottle holds 1½ pints of liquid.

As an action, you can spread a single bag of caltrops to cover a 5-foot-square area. Any creature that enters the area must succeed on a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw or stop moving and take 1 piercing damage. Until the creature regains at least 1 hit point, its walking speed is reduced by 10 feet. A creature moving through the area at half speed doesnt need to make the saving throw.
For 1 hour, a candle sheds bright light in a 5-foot radius and dim light for an additional 5 feet.
a container designed to hold or protect something.
This wooden case can hold up to twenty crossbow bolts.
A chain has 10 hit points. It can be burst with a successful DC 20 Strength check.
a soft white limestone (calcium carbonate) formed from the skeletal remains of sea creatures; used to write or mark dry surfaces

A climbers kit includes special pitons, boot tips, gloves, and a harness. You can use the climbers kit as an action to anchor yourself; when you do, you cant fall more than 25 feet from the point where you anchored yourself, and you cant climb more than 25 feet away from that point without undoing the anchor.

A component pouch is a small, watertight leather belt pouch that has compartments to hold all the material components and other special items you need to cast your spells, except for those components that have a specific cost (as indicated in a spells description).
A crampon is a metal plate with spikes that is strapped to the sole of a boot. A creature wearing crampons cant fall prone while moving across slippery ice.
Using a crowbar grants advantage to Strength checks where the crowbars leverage can be applied.
Holds 1 pint of liquid.
a device with iron claws, attached to a rope and used for dragging or grasping
a tool with a heavy metal head mounted at right angles at the end of a handle, used for jobs such as breaking things and driving in nails.
a large, heavy hammer used for such jobs as breaking rocks and driving in fence posts.
an invertible device with two connected glass bulbs containing sand that takes an hour to pass from the upper to the lower bulb.
colored fluid used for writing, drawing, printing, or duplicating.
an instrument for writing or drawing with ink

Insect repellent can be purchased in Port Nyanzaru in two forms: blocks of incense or a greasy salve. The merchant prince Kwayothe controls the sale of both. Neither kind of repellent protects against giant insects or the vile swarms of insects described in appendix A of the Monster Manual.

When lit, it burns for 8 hours and repels normal insects within a 20-foot-radius centered on it.
A jug holds 1 gallon of liquid.
A lamp casts bright light in a 15-foot radius and dim light for an additional 30 feet. Once lit, it burns for 6 hours on a flask (1 pint) of oil.
A bullseye lantern casts bright light in a 60-foot cone and dim light for an additional 60 feet. Once lit, it burns for 6 hours on a flask (1 pint) of oil.

A hooded lantern casts bright light in a 30-foot radius and dim light for an additional 30 feet. Once lit, it burns for 6 hours on a flask (1 pint) of oil. As an action, you can lower the hood, reducing the light to dim light in a 5-foot radius.

A key is provided with the lock. Without the key, a creature proficient with thieves tools can pick this lock with a successful DC 15 Dexterity check. Your DM may decide that better locks are available for higher prices.

This lens allows a closer look at small objects. It is also useful as a substitute for flint and steel when starting fires. Lighting a fire with a magnifying glass requires light as bright as sunlight to focus, tinder to ignite, and about 5 minutes for the fire to ignite. A magnifying glass grants advantage on any ability check made to appraise or inspect an item that is small or highly detailed.

These metal restraints can bind a Small or Medium creature. Escaping the manacles requires a successful DC 20 Dexterity check. Breaking them requires a successful DC 20 Strength check. Each set of manacles comes with one key. Without the key, a creature proficient with thieves tools can pick the manacles lock with a successful DC 15 Dexterity check. Manacles have 15 hit points.
A switch made of flint is built into the bowl of this fine wooden smoking pipe. With a few flicks of the switch, the pipe lights itself.
This tin box contains a cup and simple cutlery. The box clamps together, and one side can be used as a cooking pan and the other as a plate or shallow bowl.
a reflective surface, made of steel, that reflects a clear image.

Add-On-Materials: Flesh, Gem, Metal, Mineral, Perfume, Plant
Text: Oil usually comes in a clay flask that holds 1 pint. As an action, you can splash the oil in this flask onto a creature within 5 feet of you or throw it up to 20 feet, shattering it on impact. Make a ranged attack against a target creature or object, treating the oil as an improvised weapon. On a hit, the target is covered in oil. If the target takes any fire damage before the oil dries (after 1 minute), the target takes an additional 5 fire damage from the burning oil. You can also pour a flask of oil on the ground to cover a 5-foot-square area, provided that the surface is level. If lit, the oil burns for 2 rounds and deals 5 fire damage to any creature that enters the area or ends its turn in the area. A creature can take this damage only once per turn.
material manufactured in thin sheets from the pulp of wood or other fibrous substances, used for writing, drawing, or printing on, or as wrapping material.
a stiff, flat, thin material made from the prepared skin of an animal and used as a durable writing surface
a fragrant liquid typically made from essential oils extracted from flowers and spices, used to impart a pleasant smell to ones body or clothes.

a tool consisting of a long handle set at right angles in the middle of a curved iron or steel bar with a point at one end and a chisel edge or point at the other, used for breaking up hard ground or rock.
a peg or spike driven into a rock or crack to support a climber or a rope.
An iron pot holds 1 gallon of liquid.
a long, loose outer garment.
Rope, whether made of hemp or silk, has 2 hit points and can be burst with a DC 17 Strength check.
Rope, whether made of hemp or silk, has 2 hit points and can be burst with a DC 20 Strength check.

A scale includes a small balance, pans, and a suitable assortment of weights up to 2 pounds. With it, you can measure the exact weight of small objects, such as raw precious metals or trade goods, to help determine their worth.
a mixture of beeswax and pigment, softened by heating and used to make seals.
a tool with a broad flat blade and typically upturned sides, used for moving coal, earth, snow or other material.
A small whistle used for signaling
Each signet ring has a distinctive design carved into it. When you press this ring into warm sealing wax, you leave an identifying mark.
Snowshoes reduce the likelihood of their wearer getting stuck in the deep snow.
Essential for wizards, a spellbook is a leather-bound tome with 100 blank vellum pages suitable for recording spells.
Standard iron spikes typically used with a hammer.
Objects viewed through a spyglass are magnified to twice their size.
A simple and portable canvas shelter, a tent sleeps two.
A vial can hold up to 4 ounces of liquid.
Adamantine Ingots used extensively for trading and investment
Copper Ingots used extensively for forging and casting.
a soft white fibrous substance that surrounds the seeds of a tropical and subtropical plant and is used as textile fiber and thread for sewing.
Gold Ingots used extensively for trading and investment
Iron Ingots used extensively for forging and casting.
cloth woven from flax
Platinum Ingots used extensively for trading and investment
Silver Ingots used extensively for trading and investment

Barding is armor designed to protect an animals head, neck, chest, and body. The cost is four times the equivalent armor made for humanoids, and it weighs twice as much.

This armor consists of a fitted metal chest piece worn with supple leather. Although it leaves the legs and arms relatively unprotected, this armor provides good protection for the wearers vital organs while leaving the wearer relatively unencumbered.

Barding is armor designed to protect an animals head, neck, chest, and body. The cost is four times the equivalent armor made for humanoids, and it weighs twice as much.

Barding is armor designed to protect an animals head, neck, chest, and body. The cost is four times the equivalent armor made for humanoids, and it weighs twice as much.

Barding is armor designed to protect an animals head, neck, chest, and body. The cost is four times the equivalent armor made for humanoids, and it weighs twice as much.

Half plate consists of shaped metal plates that cover most of the wearers body. It does not include leg protection beyond simple greaves that are attached with leather straps.

Barding is armor designed to protect an animals head, neck, chest, and body. The cost is four times the equivalent armor made for humanoids, and it weighs twice as much.

This crude armor consists of thick furs and pelts. It is commonly worn by barbarian tribes, evil humanoids, and other folk who lack access to the tools and materials needed to create better armor.

Barding is armor designed to protect an animals head, neck, chest, and body. The cost is four times the equivalent armor made for humanoids, and it weighs twice as much.

The breastplate and shoulder protectors of this armor are made of leather that has been stiffened by being boiled in oil. The rest of the armor is made of softer and more flexible materials.

Barding is armor designed to protect an animals head, neck, chest, and body. The cost is four times the equivalent armor made for humanoids, and it weighs twice as much.

This armor is leather armor with heavy rings sewn into it. The rings help reinforce the armor against blows from swords and axes. Ring mail is inferior to chain mail, and its usually worn only by those who cant afford better armor.

This armor is leather armor with heavy rings sewn into it. The rings help reinforce the armor against blows from swords and axes. Ring mail is inferior to chain mail, and its usually worn only by those who cant afford better armor.

This armor consists of a coat and leggings (and perhaps a separate skirt) of leather covered with overlapping pieces of metal, much like the scales of a fish. The suit includes gauntlets.

Barding is armor designed to protect an animals head, neck, chest, and body. The cost is four times the equivalent armor made for humanoids, and it weighs twice as much.

Spiked armor is a rare type of medium armor made by dwarves. It consists of a leather coat and leggings covered with spikes that are usually made of metal.

Barding is armor designed to protect an animals head, neck, chest, and body. The cost is four times the equivalent armor made for humanoids, and it weighs twice as much.

This armor is made of narrow vertical strips of metal riveted to a backing of leather that is worn over cloth padding. Flexible chain mail protects the joints.

Barding is armor designed to protect an animals head, neck, chest, and body. The cost is four times the equivalent armor made for humanoids, and it weighs twice as much.

Made from tough but flexible leather, studded leather is reinforced with close-set rivets or spikes.
If you are proficient with a gaming set, you can add your proficiency bonus to ability checks you make to play a game with that set.
If you are proficient with a gaming set, you can add your proficiency bonus to ability checks you make to play a game with that set.
Ammunition made of or coated with adamantine is unusually effective when used to break objects. Whenever a piece of adamantine ammunition hits an object, the hit is a critical hit.

Arrows are used with a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a ranged attack. Each time you attack with the weapon, you expend one piece of ammunition. Drawing the ammunition from a quiver, case, or other container is part of the attack (you need a free hand to load a one-handed weapon). At the end of the battle, you can recover half your expended ammunition by taking a minute to search the battlefield.
Bone arrows gain any damage benefits from CR value, otherwise act as normal ammunition

Crossbow bolts are used with a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a ranged attack. Each time you attack with the weapon, you expend one piece of ammunition. Drawing the ammunition from a quiver, case, or other container is part of the attack (you need a free hand to load a one-handed weapon). At the end of the battle, you can recover half your expended ammunition by taking a minute to search the battlefield.
1d8 slashing; versatile (1d10)

2d4 slashing; two-handed, heavy

Special. If you attack with a double-bladed scimitar as part of the Attack action on your turn, you can use a bonus action immediately after to make a melee attack with it. This attack deals 1d4 slashing damage on a hit, instead of 2d4.
1d8 bludgeoning
1d10 slashing; heavy, reach, two-handed

On a hit with this weapon, the wielder can forgo dealing damage and attempt to trip the target, in which case the target must succeed on a Strength saving throw or fall prone. The DC is 8 + the wielders Strength modifier + the wielders proficiency bonus.

1d12 piercing; reach 
special: You have disadvantage when you use a lance to attack a target within 5 feet of you. Also, a lance requires two hands to wield when you aren’t mounted.

Special: also counts as a shield adding the normal +2 bonus to AC

Special: A large or smaller creature hit by a bolas must succeed on a DC 10 dexterity saving throw or be restrained by it. A creature can break free by using its action to make a DC 10 strength check or dealing 5 slashing damage to the bolas.
1d8 piercing; ammunition (150/600), heavy, two-handed

special, thrown (5/15)
Special: A Large or smaller creature hit by a net is restrained until it is freed. A net has no effect on creatures that are form less, or creatures that are Huge or larger. A creature can use its action to make a DC 10 Strength check, freeing itself or another creature within its reach on a success. Dealing 5 slashing damage to the net (AC 10) also frees the creature without harming it, ending the effect and destroying the net.W hen you use an action, bonus action, or reaction to attack with a net, you can make only one attack regardless of the number of attacks you can normally make

Melee weapons made of or coated with adamantine are unusually effective when used to break objects. Whenever an adamantine weapon hits an object, the hit is a critical hit.
While weilding a bone weapon you have +2 to all intimidation checks, and all attacks that deal slashing damage with this weapon becomes bludgeoning.

An item made from mithral weighs half as much as the same item made from other metals. If the weapon isn’t Heavy, it becomes Light. If it is already listed as Light it gains the Finesse property. If the weapon is Two-Handed it is now instead Versatile. 
Mithral ammunition it too light to be effective.
Mithral is too light to effectively make heavy weapons.

Orichalcum weapons lose all Light and Finesse properties.  A Orichalcum weapon grants a +2 bonus to hit against fey creatures. If the creature wielding it has a strength score of 15 or higher,  add +1 bonus to damage rolls.

Some monsters that have immunity or resistance to nonmagical weapons are susceptible to silver weapons, so cautious adventurers invest extra coin to plate their weapons with silver. You can silver a single weapon for 100 gp. This cost represents not only the price of the silver, but the time and expertise needed to add silver to the weapon without making it less effective.
Livestock mainly reared for eggs and meat.
Livestock reared for milk, meat, and hide
Livestock reared for milk, meat, fur, and skins
Generally used as  draft animals (used for plowing, for transport (pulling carts, hauling wagons and even riding), for threshing grain by trampling)
Livestock raised for meat, hide, or occasionally as trained foragers
Livestock raised for wool, meat (mutton/lamb), and milk
joins the two ends of the bow stave and launches the arrow; It takes a short rest to affix the string to a bow.
an archers portable case for holding arrows. A quiver can hold up to 20 arrows.

Blowgun needles are used with a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a ranged attack. Each time you attack with the weapon, you expend one piece of ammunition. Drawing the ammunition from a quiver, case, or other container is part of the attack (you need a free hand to load a one-handed weapon). At the end of the battle, you can recover half your expended ammunition by taking a minute to search the battlefield.

Some monsters that have immunity or resistance to nonmagical weapons are susceptible to silver ammunition, so cautious adventurers invest extra coin to plate their ammunition in silver. You can silver ten pieces of ammunition for 100 gp. This cost represents not only the price of the silver, but the time and expertise needed to add silver to the ammunition without making it less effective.

Sling bullets are used with a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a ranged attack. Each time you attack with the weapon, you expend one piece of ammunition. Drawing the ammunition from a quiver, case, or other container is part of the attack (you need a free hand to load a one-handed weapon). At the end of the battle, you can recover half your expended ammunition by taking a minute to search the battlefield.
1d6 piercing; ammunition (30/120), light, loading
1d10 piercing; ammunition (100/400), heavy, loading, two-handed

2d6 piercing; ammunition (280/1,120), oversized, two-handed

This unique weapon has a Strength requirement of 18 or higher. The bow shoots oversized arrows that deal piercing damage equal to 2d6 + the wielders Strength modifier.

Oversized. Creatures that are Medium have disadvantage on attack rolls with oversized weapons; small or tiny creatures cannot use an oversized weapon. An oversized weapons size and bulk make it too large for a Medium creature to use effectively.
A backpack can hold one cubic foot or 30 pounds of gear. You can also strap items, such as a bedroll or a coil of rope, to the outside of a backpack.
A barrel can hold 40 gallons of liquid or 4 cubic feet of solids.
A bucket holds 3 gallons of liquid or ½ cubic foot of solids.
A chest holds 12 cubic feet or 300 pounds of gear.
a structure consisting of a series of bars or steps between two upright lengths of wood, metal, or rope, used for climbing up or down something.
a long, slender, rounded piece of wood or metal, typically used with one end placed in the ground as a support for something.

A cloth or leather pouch can hold up to 20 sling bullets or 50 blowgun needles, among other things. A compartmentalized pouch for holding spell components is called a component pouch. A pouch can hold up to ⅕ cubic foot or 6 pounds of gear.
You can use a portable ram to break down doors. When doing so, you gain a +4 bonus on the Strength check. One other character can help you use the ram, giving you advantage on this check.
Rations consist of dry foods suitable for extended travel, including jerky, dried fruit, hardtack, and nuts.
A sack can hold up to 1 cubic foot or 30 pounds of gear.
A commodity used for bathing.

This small container holds flint, fire steel, and tinder (usually dry cloth soaked in light oil) used to kindle a fire. Using it to light a torch—or anything else with abundant, exposed fuel—takes an action. Lighting any other fire takes 1 minute.
A torch burns for 1 hour, providing bright light in a 20-foot radius and dim light for an additional 20 feet. If you make a melee attack with a burning torch and hit, it deals 1 fire damage.
A waterskin can hold up to 4 pints of liquid.
Alchemists supplies enable a character to produce useful concoctions, such as acid or alchemists fire.
Brewing is the art of producing beer. Not only does beer serve as an alcoholic beverage, but the process of brewing purifies water.

Calligraphy treats writing as a delicate, beautiful art. Calligraphers produce text that is pleasing to the eye, using a style that is difficult to forge. Their supplies also give them some ability to examine scripts and determine if they are legitimate, since a calligraphers training involves long hours of studying writing and attempting to replicate its style and design.
Skill at carpentry enables a character to construct wooden structures. A carpenter can build a house, a shack, a wooden cabinet, or similar items.

Using cartographers tools, you can create accurate maps to make travel easier for yourself and those who come after you. These maps can range from large-scale depictions of mountain ranges to diagrams that show the layout of a dungeon level.
Although the cobblers trade might seem too humble for an adventurer, a good pair of boots will see a character across rugged wilderness and through deadly dungeons.
Adventuring is a hard life. With a cook along on the journey, your meals will be much better than the typical mix of hardtack and dried fruit.
The perfect tool for anyone who wants to engage in trickery, a disguise kit enables its owner to adopt a false identity.
This kit includes a wooden rod, silken line, corkwood bobbers, steel hooks, lead sinkers, velvet lures, and narrow netting.
A forgery kit is designed to duplicate documents and to make it easier to copy a persons seal or signature.
Someone who is proficient with glassblowers tools has not only the ability to shape glass, but also specialized knowledge of the methods used to produce glass objects.
Proficiency with an herbalism kit allows you to identify plants and safely collect their useful elements.
Training with jewelers tools includes the basic techniques needed to beautify gems. It also gives you expertise in identifying precious stones.
Knowledge of leatherworking extends to lore concerning animal hides and their properties. It also confers knowledge of leather armor and similar goods.
Masons tools allow you to craft stone structures, including walls and buildings crafted from brick.

This set of instruments is used for navigation at sea. Proficiency with navigators tools lets you chart a ships course and follow navigation charts. In addition, these tools allow you to add your proficiency bonus to any ability check you make to avoid getting lost at sea.
Proficiency with painters supplies represents your ability to paint and draw. You also acquire an understanding of art history, which can aid you in examining works of art.

The Poisoner’s kit is often just a converted Herbalism kit, capable of crafting concoctions designed to end a life rather than save it. It allows you to apply toxins and create them from various materials. Your knowledge of poisons also helps you craft antitoxins to treat them.
Potters tools are used to create a variety of ceramic objects, most typically pots and similar vessels.
Smiths tools allow you to work metal, heating it to alter its shape, repair damage, or work raw ingots into useful items.
Perhaps the most common tools used by adventurers, thieves tools are designed for picking locks and foiling traps. Proficiency with the tools also grants you a general knowledge of traps and locks.
Tinkers are capable of crafting more complicated items that often involve some mechanical work such as scales, fishing tackle, and other rudimentary mechanical marvels.
Weavers tools allow you to create cloth and tailor it into articles of clothing.
Woodcarvers tools allow you to craft intricate objects from wood, such as wooden tokens or arrows.
Proficiency with a gaming set applies to one type of game, such as Three-Dragon Ante or games of chance that use dice.
If you are proficient with a gaming set, you can add your proficiency bonus to ability checks you make to play a game with that set.
Proficiency with a musical instrument indicates you are familiar with the techniques used to play it. You also have knowledge of some songs commonly performed with that instrument.
Proficiency with a musical instrument indicates you are familiar with the techniques used to play it. You also have knowledge of some songs commonly performed with that instrument.
Proficiency with a musical instrument indicates you are familiar with the techniques used to play it. You also have knowledge of some songs commonly performed with that instrument.
Proficiency with a musical instrument indicates you are familiar with the techniques used to play it. You also have knowledge of some songs commonly performed with that instrument.
Proficiency with a musical instrument indicates you are familiar with the techniques used to play it. You also have knowledge of some songs commonly performed with that instrument.

Add-On-Materials: Bone, Dye, Gem, Metal, Mineral, Textile

Proficiency with a musical instrument indicates you are familiar with the techniques used to play it. You also have knowledge of some songs commonly performed with that instrument.

A Large and often-storied house dedicated to housing members of a guild, typically all of a single profession. Contains semi-private quarters for up to 25 individuals, and a free dining hall that costs neither expansion unts nor gold.

Expansion Units: 2

A simple but perhaps elaborately and colorfully adorned set of shacks, tents, or shops - each holding wares. Comes equipped with private lodging for 5 important persons and bunks or hammocks for up to 45 travellers, traders, or passing merchants. This structure also includes a caravansary.

Expansion Units: 2

An underground dwelling, dank, pungent, and dark. Perhaps composed of mineshafts, carved stone, or ancient sunken ruins. Dimly lit by torches, lava, or phosphorescent fungi. Contains communal living quarters for up to 50 tightly packed humanoids, and free jails that cost neither expansion units nor gold.

Expansion Units: 3

A structure equipped with heavy stone walls, turrets, and spires. There is a master room, as well as private rooms for up to 50 distinguished guests. This structure can house up to 450 persons in less comfortable, occasionally communal living space. This structure comes with a war room at no additional costs.

Expansion Units: 6

A beautiful structure worthy of a king, containing pseronal chambers for the owners, private quarters for up to 200 distinuished guests, and common residences for up to 1,800 servants and soldiers. This structure comes with one free expansion of the owners choice as long as it would cost one expansion unit.

Expansion Units: 10
Plots of land; small plots 100-1000gp. Larger plots run 5000gp

A small to medium cozy hovel, or home that can house a maximum of 5 people in close quarters. Made of thatch, lumber, brick, or similar. You may build one expansion at half of its gold cost here.

Expansion Units: 1

A fine manor house on a wide tract of land, expertly manicured or tailored how you wish. Contains private rooms for up to 15 individuals, as well as lower quality and well hidden semi-private quarters for a serving staff of up to 35 persons., as well as a library.

Expansion Units: 4

A military structure containing crivate quarters for up to 25 officers and common bunks for up to 225 soldiers and staff, and an armory.

Expansion Units: 3

A large single spire that includes 25 occupants, tightly packed bunks for up to 100 visitors, and a stables.

Expansion Units: 3

Often dedicated to a particular deity or holy/monastic order. Made plain or ornate, befitting its order, out of local stone or wood. Contains mostly communal living quarters for up to 100 persons, and a garden.

Expansion Units: 6

Carved in the image of a god or pantheon, this place contains communal bunks suitable for 100 pilgrims or acolytes, and private quarters for up to 25 ranking members of the clergy, as well as a chapel.

Expansion Units: 6

Contains lavish private quarters for up to 10 instructors and communal, living for up to 90 students, in addition to a theater equppied with seating and a stage.

Expansion Units: 6
Speed: 40, Carrying Capacity: 195 lb.
Speed: 40, Carrying Capacity: 540 lb.

A sled dog (use the wolf stat block in appendix A of the Monster Manual) costs 50 gp and can pull 360 pounds.

Sled dogs must take a short rest after pulling a sled for 1 hour; otherwise, they gain one level of exhaustion.
An axe beaks splayed toes allow it to run across snow, and it can carry as much weight as a mule.
Speed: 50, Carrying Capacity: 480 lb.
Speed: 40, Carrying Capacity: 1320 lb.
Griffon eggs are worth 350 gp apiece on the open market, while young are worth 700 gp each. Professional trainers charge 150 gp to rear or train a griffon.
Speed: 60, Carrying Capacity: 480 lb.
Speed: 40, Carrying Capacity: 420 lb.
Speed: 40, Carrying Capacity: 225 lb.
Speed: 60, Carrying Capacity: 540 lb.
The breastplate and shoulder protectors of this armor are made of leather that has been stiffened by being boiled in oil. The rest of the armor is made of softer and more flexible materials.
Made from tough but flexible leather, studded leather is reinforced with close-set rivets or spikes.
This crude armor consists of thick furs and pelts. It is commonly worn by barbarian tribes, evil humanoids, and other folk who lack access to the tools and materials needed to create better armor.
An arcane focus is a special item designed to channel the power of arcane spells. A sorcerer, warlock, or wizard can use such an item as a spellcasting focus.
An arcane focus is a special item designed to channel the power of arcane spells. A sorcerer, warlock, or wizard can use such an item as a spellcasting focus.
An arcane focus is a special item designed to channel the power of arcane spells. A sorcerer, warlock, or wizard can use such an item as a spellcasting focus.

The vital quality herbs can be ground, dissolved in a liquid, heated, and ingested. A creature that ingests 1 ounce of herb in this fashion regains 1 hit point. A creature that ingests more than 5 ounces in a 24-hour period gains no additional benefit and must succeed on a DC 11 Constitution saving throw or fall unconscious for 1 hour. The unconscious creature awakens if it takes at least 5 damage on one turn.

These dried leaves of the Olisuba bush, when steeped to make a tea, can help a body recover from strenuous activity. If you drink a dose of Olisuba tea during a long rest, your exhaustion level is reduced by 2 instead of 1 at the end of that long rest.

A psychoactive liquid that smells and tastes like your favorite beverage, essence of dreamlily is a Sarlonan opiate. First imported to help manage pain during the Last War, its now the most commonly abused substance in Sharn. Though dreamlily isnt illegal if used for medicinal purposes, its heavily taxed, and thus most dreamlily is smuggled in and sold on the black market. Dreamlily dens can be found across the lower wards. Consuming dreamlily causes disorienting euphoria and brings about remarkable resistance to pain. A creature under the effects of dreamlily is poisoned for 1 hour. While poisoned in this way, the creature is immune to fear, and the first time it drops to 0 hit points without being killed outright, it drops to 1 hit point instead. A dose of dreamlily costs around 1 gp, or up to ten times that if purchased through legal channels. There are many varieties of the drug, however, and the duration or the price might vary accordingly.

Feys blood is a potent and highly addictive stimulant. In addition to inducing euphoria, it can enhance spellcasting ability or even temporarily imbue a user with the ability to cast sorcerer spells. The drugs effects are potentially dangerous and always unpredictable. The specific effects of dragons blood are up to you, but you can take inspiration from the Wild Magic Surge table in the Players Handbook.

A red-brown mossy herb that, when heated (even from the friction of rubbing it between your fingers), releases wisps of smoke that create feelings of euphoria when inhaled and is used as a recreational drug. Fire-herb is highly addictive, limiting its medicinal use, though it is sometimes used to reduce cranial swelling and offer pain relief.
small plant with long purple leaves, gives a sense of comfort and nostalgia, as well as blocks out your super-ego and makes you give into base desires.

This tarry substance harvested from the dark boughs of the deaths head willow is a powerful intoxicant. It can be smoked as a concentrate or injected directly into the bloodstream. A creature subjected to a dose of black sap cannot be charmed or frightened for 1d6 hours.

For each dose of black sap consumed, a creature must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or become poisoned for 2d4 hours—an effect that is cumulative with multiple doses.

This bitter chartreuse concoction is distilled from a fungus native to the Blightshore badlands. The sickly green liqueur harbors potent psychedelic properties. Provided it is neither a construct nor undead, a creature subjected to a dose of blight ichor gains advantage on Intelligence and Wisdom checks, as well as vulnerability to psychic damage, for 1 hour. For each dose of blight ichor consumed, the creature must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or become poisoned for 1d6 hours and suffer the effects of a confusion spell for 1 minute. An undead creature subjected to a dose of blight ichor gains advantage on all Dexterity checks and is immune to the frightened condition for 1 hour.
Standard equipment used to direct a mount.
Standard saddlebags that can be attached to a mounts saddle.

Barding is armor designed to protect an animals head, neck, chest, and body. The cost is four times the equivalent armor made for humanoids, and it weighs twice as much.

Padded armor consists of quilted layers of cloth and batting.
Standard feed typically consumed by a mount per day.
An exotic saddle is required for riding any aquatic or flying mount.
A military saddle braces the rider, helping you keep your seat on an active mount in battle. It gives you advantage on any check you make to remain mounted.
A standard saddle for a pack mount.
A standard saddle for a riding mount.
a four-wheeled passenger vehicle pulled by two or more horses.
a strong open vehicle with two or four wheels, typically used for carrying loads and pulled by a horse.
a four-wheeled carriage with back seats and a coachmans seat.
a vehicle, typically on runners, for conveying goods or passengers over snow or ice, either pushed or pulled, or drawn by horses, or dogs.
heavy four-wheeled vehicle pulled by draught animals or on occasion by humans, used for transporting goods, commodities, agricultural materials, supplies and sometimes people

Padded armor consists of quilted layers of cloth and batting.

The wearer has disadvantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks.
a type of beer with a bitter flavor and higher alcoholic content
a type of beer with a bitter flavor and higher alcoholic content
nutrient-rich liquid food produced by the mammary glands of mammals
an alcoholic drink made from fermented grape juice.
an alcoholic drink made from fermented grape juice of exeptional quality.
The fermenting process of goodberries have reduced the health benefit, but it has a sweet after taste; dessert wine.
an elaborate and formal meal (price per person)
Meal of moderate quality, examples include; Bacon and egg sandwich, Roast lamb and cheese, Hunters Pie
Meal of modest quality examples include; Ham and cheese on rye, Roast goat and cheese, Rabbit and potato plate.
Meal of the finest quality, exmples include; Truffle Omelet, Roc Meat portion, Dragon Steak, Boar Ham Steak and Eggs, Dragon Turtle Soup, Sahuagin Caviar.
A meal of low quality and cheap foodstuffs some examples of plates include; "meat" stick, roasted locusts, stock stew, small bird plater.
Meal of high quality, examples include; Bacon stuffed bread, Grilled Salmon, Roasted Bullywug Legs, Bloodhawk Egg omlete, Baked Goose Breast, Crocodile Steak.
